20 Dec 2025

Generative AI bores me to tears and that's a privileged stance

The gaps between having an idea burrow its way into my brain and putting it in a blog post are getting shorter. The last one about loneliness in blogging and online spaces took me weeks and this one, about my boredom with generative AI, has taken‚Ä¶ weeks but less weeks so it‚Äôs an improvement.

I wanted to talk about my general mental fatigue and emotional malaise over all things generative AI. And while that will form the basis of this post, I read a very good article that made me realise that this tiredness is a privileged perspective.[1]

Privilege in the era of AI

On 3rd December, Josh Collinsworth wrote an article titled ‚ÄúAI optimism is a class privilege‚Äù. In it, he outlined the idea of AI optimism requireing a level of privilege that a lot of people can‚Äôt afford. It‚Äôs also something of a ticking time bomb fallacy due to mass proliferation.

That‚Äôs the thing about being bullish on AI: to focus on its benefits to you, you‚Äôre forced to ignore its costs to others.

As with any good article I find, there are tons of quotables which means you should read the whole thing instead. Josh touched on a lot of topics that I had been thinking about over the last few years but not from this perspective.

I don‚Äôt confront people about their AI optimism because it‚Äôd be a futile task and seem like an unprovoked attack. I have an itchy trigger finger with this tech, knowing what it‚Äôs been used for over and over and over again, but a common response to seemingly any AI use case is ‚Äúinteresting!‚Äù and I have to ask: which part is interesting, exactly?

The Generation Game where everybody loses

I‚Äôve mentioned before how we should be more specific about what AI tech we‚Äôre referring to in our rhetoric since AI is an umbrella term (and a lot like an orange. This helps at a relatively basic level when you‚Äôre trying to figure out the difference between an AI-generated image and an image enhanced using AI tech (see: Will Smith concert pics)

But Josh‚Äôs article made me think if the distinctions make a difference in terms of the outcomes. Popular LLMs are made by the same 5 companies who are destroying the planet. Open source models don‚Äôt guzzle as much electricity and water and can be run locally but they‚Äôre not as powerful so get left behind in peoples‚Äô minds and compute power is compute power at the end of the day‚Äîelectricity will increase no matter whose power you use. As for harms, they scale depending on the model but you‚Äôre still at risk of exposure. And what about the idea of use as endorsement? It‚Äôs not out of the realms of possibility that advocating for open source models could lead someone to try out a proprietry model due to the former‚Äôs weaker output and find their ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù.

Single bored computing

All of the above swirl around in my mind whenever I see a new generative AI ‚Äúthing‚Äù. It could be at work, on social media, or in a blog post I‚Äôve read by someone I actually respect (even if they write about people that I don‚Äôt respect). And I‚Äôm bored. I‚Äôm so so bored. To the point that it actually makes me a little queasy and I ache a little.

And the reason why I‚Äôm so bored is because none of this remotely interests me. It‚Äôs all about ‚Äúcontext engineering‚Äù and make it look like they‚Äôre putting in a great deal of thought into the models which allegedly put a great deal of thought into the outputs. But it‚Äôs the blind leading the blind. If something works for you, it might not work elsewhere or it could be improved in some way but you‚Äôd never know since you stopped once it ‚Äúworked‚Äù.

The evangelising makes me want to take my brain out and wash it with soap and water (I want to keep the wrinkles in tact so I didn‚Äôt opt for smoothing in this metaphor). Nothing here is new or original. Every idea is just querying a machine instead of asking a human and paying them if that‚Äôs what you should have been doing. A friend of mine reminded me that perhaps the idea wasn‚Äôt to make AI tech successful and bring us AGI (whatever that means anymore) but to make sure that humans don‚Äôt get paid for labour at the biggest scale in history. With that, they‚Äôre doing well. Even if companies are losing money in the process, it‚Äôs recoverable. For regular folks, it isn‚Äôt‚Äîat least not in the same way.

Thoughts and actions

And again, I‚Äôm back to battling between finding the whole thing tedious and asking myself whether that‚Äôs helpful or meaningul. Who cares if I‚Äôm bored if I‚Äôm still using the tech and contributing to all this mess? I think I‚Äôve mentioned it before in another blog but I‚Äôm surprised more of my friends haven‚Äôt disconnected from me (more than usual). I‚Äôve been fairly vocal in my criticisms but I use Gemini at work (not mandatory but it‚Äôs heavily promoted) and dip into Gemini sometimes for code troubleshooting when I can‚Äôt find the answer in docs or Stack Overflow.

The one area I do enjoy in all of this is around embeddings and NLP. I think they‚Äôre cool and lean more towards machine learning techniques than the kind of generative AI that most general consumers are used to. And they‚Äôve been in use long before this boom with search engines and other related tech. That‚Äôs not to say that they are immune to biases and harms such as most models being heavily Anglocentric but it‚Äôs as far away from the really bad stuff as I can short of stopping my use altogether.

Professional assassination?

Whenever there are chats at work about AI, I‚Äôm usually the one posting cautionary tales and meta-opinions on why critical thinking is important. Early on, I did a webinar where I said similar things and I‚Äôve even gone as far as saying AI should be a last resort in processes. So maybe this post and others like it don‚Äôt look so good from a professional perspective. Or maybe people are humouring me when they say ‚Äúthat‚Äôs interesting‚Äù (lol) but push ahead anyway because I guess they can‚Äôt slow down now or whatever the popular ideology is with this tech.

Who knows, maybe I‚Äôll lose my job over my posts instead of the tech itself. But I stand by my criticisms because I stand by people over technology and big tech companies performing harmful practices behind brands and pledges. If nobody listens to what I say or takes heed, I can at least say that I made my intentions and impacts clear and I can live with what I‚Äôve said and done.

I will remain bored at the latest AI trend. I will continue to cringe when I see people in my direct field talk about all these things I feel like I should know but don‚Äôt want to because it‚Äôll plunge me deeper into places I don‚Äôt want to go. And I‚Äôll keep using open source models to build embeddings for little personal projects like finding out which Monster Rancher monsters are similar to Pok√©mon based on embeddings of their names and descriptions. And as long as I stay alive and don‚Äôt lose my job (yet???), those actions will be propped up by my privileges.

I guess I‚Äôll be okay. For now.

1Josh‚Äôs article makes it quite clear, to me at least, that no one is immune and while I don‚Äôt expect to lose my job tomorrow, I must assume that my chances of losing it are a non-zero value unless I ‚Äúembrace it‚Äù
